member.name: F:DoubleAgent.Control.BalloonStyleFlags.AutoHide
member.summary: The word balloon is hidden automatically after a short delay.

remarks.para: When the style is set, the word balloon automatically hides when spoken output completes. When it's not set, the word balloon remains displayed until the next or call, the character is hidden, or the user clicks or drags the character.

member.name: F:DoubleAgent.Control.BalloonStyleFlags.AutoPace
member.summary: The text in the word balloon is shown one word at a time.

remarks.para: When the style is set, the word balloon paces its text output based on the current output rate, for example one word at a time. When output exceeds the size of the word balloon, the text is automatically scrolled. When it's not set, all text included in a or request is displayed at once.

member.name: F:DoubleAgent.Control.BalloonStyleFlags.Enabled
member.summary: The word balloon is enabled.

remarks.para: When the style is set, the word balloon appears when the or method is used, unless the user overrides this setting in the Advanced Character Options window. When it's not set, the word balloon does not appear.

member.name: F:DoubleAgent.Control.BalloonStyleFlags.ShowPartialLines
member.summary: Partial lines are shown when the word balloon text scrolls (for a word balloon that's not SizeToText).

remarks.para: When the style is set, the word balloon will show partial lines at the bottom as it scrolls its text. When it's not set, only full lines are shown. This style only applies when the style is not set.

member.name: F:DoubleAgent.Control.BalloonStyleFlags.SizeToText
member.summary: The word balloon is automatically resized to fit the speech or thought text.

remarks.para: When the style is set, the word balloon automatically adjusts the height of the word balloon to the current size of the text for the or request. When it's not set, the word balloon's height is based on the property. If this style is set and you attempt to set the property, Double Agent raises an error.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.AutoConnect
member.summary: Specifies if the Double Agent control will automatically connect to the Double Agent server.
member.value:
A numeric value specifying whether automatic connection is enabled.
On a 32-bit system:
0 The control will not automatically connect to the server.
Any non-zero value The control will automatically connect to the server.
On a 64-bit system:
0 The control will not automatically connect to the server.
32 The control will automatically connect to the 32-bit server. If the 32-bit server is not installed, the 64-bit server will be used.
64 The control will automatically connect to the 64-bit server. If the 64-bit server is not installed, the 32-bit server will be used.
Any other non-zero value The control will automatically connect to server with the same architecture as the calling process. If the matching server is not installed, then the other server will be used.

remarks.para: If this property is non-zero, then the control will automatically establish a connection with the server the first time it's required. To use the control in stand-alone mode, you must set this property to zero.
For compatibility with Microsoft® Agent, the default value for this property is True.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.AutoSize
member.summary: Specifies if the ActiveX® control is automatically sized to fit the .
member.value: A boolean value that specifies if the control's size is automatically adjusted to exactly fit the .

remarks.note: This property is relevant only when the control is visible (i.e. when it's used in contained mode).

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.BackColor
member.summary: Specifies the ActiveX® control's background color.
member.value: An OLECOLOR value for the control's background color.

remarks.para: The valid range for a normal RGB color is 0 to 16,777,215 (&HFFFFFF). The high byte of a number in this range equals 0; the lower 3 bytes, from least to most significant byte, determine the amount of red, green, and blue, respectively. The red, green, and blue components are each represented by a number between 0 and 255 (&HFF).
If the high byte of an OLECOLOR is &H80, the lower 3 bytes contain a system color index.
remarks.note: This property is relevant only when the control is visible (i.e. when it's used in contained mode).

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.BorderColor

The red, green, and blue components are each represented by a number between 0 and 255 (&HFF).
If the high byte of an OLECOLOR is &H80, the lower 3 bytes contain a system color index.
remarks.note: This property is relevant only when the control is visible (i.e. when it's used in contained mode).

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.CharacterStyle
member.summary: Specifies the initial style to use when a is loaded.
member.value:
A numeric bit-field value that specifies the to apply when a is loaded:
&H00000001 = SoundEffects
The animation sound effects are played.
&H00000002 = IdleEnabled
The character enters idle mode and shows it's idling animations when it's not doing anything else.
&H00000004 = AutoPopupMenu
A right-click on the character or it's notification icon automatically shows a pop-up menu.
&H00000008 = IconShown
The character has a notification icon in the taskbar notification area.
&H00000020 = SmoothEdges
Image smoothing (antialiasing) is applied to the edges of the character's animations.
&H00000030 = Smoothed
Image smoothing (antialiasing) is applied to the character's animations.
&H00000100 = SuspendPause
All requests are paused when the client is not in the foreground.
&H00000200 = SuspendStop
All requests are stopped when the client is not in the foreground.
&H00000400 = SuspendHide
All floating windows are hidden when the client is not in the foreground.

remarks.para: Setting this property allows you to establish a default . for you application. It's initial value is , , , .

The and flags can only be changed here. Once a is loaded, these bits cannot be changed in it's property. Also, these two settings are only used the first time the character is loaded. If another client has already loaded the character, it's smoothing settings will not change. If your client application is the first client to load the character, then your smoothing settings will apply to all clients.
remarks.note: For compatibility with Microsoft® Agent, the flag is set by default. To load a without showing it's notification icon, set the flag off.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.Connected
member.summary: Specifies if the control is currently connected to the Double Agent server. The Double Agent control will work whether or not it's connected to the server, but there are are special considerations in each case. See Connected, Stand-Alone, and Contained for more information.
member.value: A boolean value specifying whether the control is connected.

remarks.para: You can manually open or close the connection to the server by changing the Connected property. When the connection state changes, any characters you've loaded are automatically unloaded. If you still have references to any objects except the control itself, any attempt to access the objects' properties or methods will fail.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.ControlCharacter
member.summary: Specifies the control's contained character.
member.value: The Object object that's contained within the visible area of the control, or an empty reference (Nothing).

remarks.para: Setting the ControlCharacter property to a Object changes the control from stand-alone mode to contained mode. Setting ControlCharacter to an empty reference changes the control from contained mode back to stand-alone mode.

Normally, the control isn't visible at runtime, but when it has a ControlCharacter it will become visible as a child window of its containing form. This is the only time the ActiveX® appearance properties, such as and , are used.
remarks.note: You cannot set the ControlCharacter property if the control is to the server.

remarks.para: When a method that returns a Object fails, there are two ways to detect the error. If RaiseRequestErrors is set, the Double Agent control will raise an error condition. member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.ActivateInput
member.summary: Signalled when a client becomes input-active.
member.param: The unique identifier of the character that has become input-active.

remarks.para: The input-active client receives mouse and speech input events for the character. Double Agent sends this event only to the client that becomes input-active.

This event can occur when the user uses your Collection, for example, by choosing a Collection entry in the Voice Commands window or in the pop-up menu window for a character. It can also occur when the user selects a character (by clicking or speaking its name), when a character becomes visible, or when the character of another client application becomes hidden.

You can also call the method with set to 2 () to explicitly make the character topmost, which results in your client application becoming input-active and triggers this event. However, this event does not occur if you use the method only to specify whether or not your client is the active client of the character.

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.ActivateInputEventHandler
member.summary: See the event.

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.ActiveClientChange
member.summary: Signalled when the active client of the character changes.
member.param: The unique identifier of the character that has become active or inactive.
True if the character has become the active client or False if it's no longer the active client.

remarks.para: When multiple clients ( instances) share the same character, the active client of the character receives mouse input (for example, click or drag events). Similarly, when multiple characters are displayed, the active client of the topmost character (also known as the input-active client) receives events.

A client application may receive this event when the user selects one of the client's entries in the character's pop-up menu or by voice command, when the client application changes its active status, or when another client terminates.
Double Agent sends this event only to the clients that are directly affected; that either become the active client or stop being the active client.

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.Click
member.summary: Signalled when the user clicks a character, or the character's notification icon.
member.param: The unique identifier of the character that was clicked.

A numeric value that identifies which mouse button was pressed and released to cause the event. The parameter is a bit field with bits corresponding to the left button (bit 0) (&H0001), right button (bit 1) (&H0002), and middle button (bit 2) (&H0004). Only one of the bits is set, indicating the mouse button that caused the event. If the character has a notification icon, and bit 13 (&H1000) is also set, the click occurred on the notification icon.

A numeric value that corresponds to the state of the Shift, Ctrl, and Alt keys when the mouse button was pressed or released. The parameter is a bit field with bits corresponding to the Shift key (bit 0) (&H0001), the Ctrl key (bit 1) (&H0002), and the Alt key (bit 2) (&H0004). A bit is set if the key is down. Some, all, or none of the bits can be set, indicating that some, all, or none of the keys are down. For example, if both Ctrl and Alt were down, the value of would be 6.
The current horizontal location of the mouse pointer, in pixels, relative to the left side of the screen.
The current vertical location of the mouse pointer, in pixels, relative to the top of the screen.

remarks.para: This event is sent only to the input-active client of a character. When the user clicks a character or its notification icon with no input-active client, Double Agent sends the event to its active client. If the character is visible ( is True), the user's action also sets the character's current input-active client as the last input-active client, sending the event to that client, and then sending the Click event. If the character is hidden ( is False), and the user clicks the character's notification icon using button 1, the character is also automatically shown.
remarks.note: Clicking a character does not disable all other character output. However, pressing the Listening key does flush the input-active character's output and triggers the event, passing a that indicates that the client's queue was interrupted.

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.ClickEventHandler
member.summary: See the event.

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.ListenComplete
member.summary: Signalled when Listening mode (speech recognition) has ended.
member.param: The unique identifier of the listening character.

The cause of the ListenComplete event.
1 = ProgramDisabled
This program turned off the Listening mode with the method.
2 = ProgramTimedOut
The Listening mode was started by this program with the method, and it timed out.
3 = UserTimedOut
The Listening mode was started with the Listening key, and it timed out.
4 = UserReleasedKey
The Listening mode was started with the Listening key, and the key was released.
5 = UserSpeechEnded
Speech recognition has produced a result.
6 = CharacterClientDeactivated
The character is no longer active or it's active client has changed.
7 = DefaultCharacterChanged
The default character was changed in the Advanced Character Options window.
8 = UserDisabled
Speech recognition was disabled in the Advanced Character Options window.

remarks.para: This event is sent to all clients when the Listening mode time-out ends, after the user releases the Listening key, when the input-active client calls the method with False, or when the user has finished speaking. You can use this event to determine when to resume spoken output.

If you turn on Listening mode using the method and then the user presses the Listening key, the Listening mode resets and continues until the Listening key time-out completes, the Listening key is released, or the user finishes speaking, whichever is later. In this situation, you will not receive a ListenComplete event until the Listening key's mode completes.
The event returns the to the clients that currently have this character loaded. All other clients receive a null (empty string).

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.ListenCompleteEventHandler
member.summary: See the event.

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.ListenStart
member.summary: Signalled when Listening mode (speech recognition) begins.
member.param: The unique identifier of the listening character.

remarks.para: This event is sent to all clients when Listening mode begins because the user pressed the Listening key or the input-active client called the method with True. You can use this event to avoid having your character speak while Listening mode is active.

If you turn on Listening mode with the method and then the user presses the Listening key, the Listening mode resets and continues until the Listening key time-out completes, the Listening key is released, or the user finishes speaking, whichever is later. In this situation, when Listening mode is already on, you will not get an additional ListenStart event when the user presses the Listening key.
The event returns the to the clients that currently have this character loaded. All other clients receive a null (empty string).

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.RequestComplete
member.summary: Signalled when Double Agent completes a queued request.
member.param: The Object that identifies the completed request.

remarks.para: This event provides a Object. Because requests are processed asynchronously, you can use this event to determine when Double Agent finishes processing a request (such as a , , or method) to synchronize this event with other requests generated by your application. Double Agent sends the event only to the client that created the reference to the Object, and only if you defined a global variable for the request reference.

example.code:
Dim MyRequest Dim Genie
Sub window_Onload control.Characters.Load "Genie","Genie.acs"
Set Genie = control.Characters("Genie")
' This syntax will generate RequestStart and RequestComplete events. Set MyRequest = Genie.Show(False) ' This syntax will not generate RequestStart and RequestComplete events. Genie.Hide False End Sub
Sub control_RequestComplete(ByVal Request) If Request Is MyRequest Then status = "Genie was shown" End Sub

remarks.para: Because animation Objects don't get assigned until Double Agent has queued the request, make sure that the Object exists before you attempt to evaluate it. For example, in Visual Basic, if you use a conditional to test whether a specific request was completed, you can use the Nothing keyword.

example.code: Sub control_RequestComplete (ByVal Request) If Not (MyRequest Is Nothing) Then If Request Is MyRequest Then '-- Do whatever End If End If End Sub

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.RequestCompleteEventHandler
member.summary: See the event.

member.name: E:DoubleAgent.Control.Control.RequestStart
member.summary: Signalled when Double Agent begins a queued request.
member.param: The Object that identifies the queued request.

remarks.para: The event provides a Object. Because requests are processed asynchronously, you can use this event to determine when Double Agent begins processing a request (such as a , , or method) and thereby synchronize this with other requests generated by your application. The event is sent only to the client that created the reference to the Object, and only if you defined a global variable for the request reference.

example.code:
Dim MyRequest Dim Genie
Sub window_Onload control.Characters.Load "Genie", "Genie.acs"
Set Genie = control.Characters("Genie")
' This syntax will generate RequestStart and RequestComplete events. Set MyRequest = Genie.Show(False)
' This syntax will not generate RequestStart and RequestComplete events. Genie.Hide False End Sub
Sub control_RequestStart(ByVal Request) If Request Is MyRequest Then status = "Genie is showing" End Sub

remarks.para: The property is 4 (InProgress) for the Object.

Because animation Objects don't get assigned until Double Agent has queued the request, make sure that the Object exists before you attempt to evaluate it. For example, in Visual Basic, if you use a conditional to test whether a specific request was completed, you can use the Nothing keyword.

example.code: Sub control_RequestStart (ByVal Request) If Not (MyRequest Is Nothing) Then If Request Is MyRequest Then '-- Do whatever End If End If End Sub

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.Control
member.summary: The Double Agent control has its own methods, properties and events, and provides access to most other objects supported by Double Agent.

remarks.para: Some programming environments may assign additional design-time or run-time properties. For example, Visual Basic adds a Name property that identifies the control, and also Left and Top properties that define the location of the control on a form, even if the control doesn't appear on the form's page at run time.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Characters.Unload(System.String)
member.summary: Unloads the character data for a loaded character.
member.param: A string value that contains the character's unique identifier, specified when the character was loaded.

remarks.para: Use this method when you no longer need a character, to free up memory used to store information about the character. If you access the character again, use the method.
This method does not return a Object.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Characters.Load(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Loads a character into the Collection.
member.param: A string value that you will use to refer to the character when it's loaded. See the property.

One of the following:
Filespec The location of a local character definition file (.ACS format)
URL The HTTP address of the character's definition file (.ACF format)
member.returns: A Object your application can use to track the status of the Load request. The Load method is asynchronous only when loading a character using the HTTP protocol.

remarks.para: You can load characters from the default location(s) by specifying only a file name. For example, specifying the following would search for Genie.acs using the default search path.

example.para: You can also specify an absolute location,
or specify your own subdirectory by using a relative path.

remarks.para: You can load the default character by omitting the second parameter of the Load method, or passing an empty string. This will load the default character from the .

You cannot load the same character (a character having the same ) more than once from a single instance of the control. Similarly, you cannot load the default character and other characters at the same time from a single instance of the control because the default character could be the same as the other character. If you attempt to do this, Double Agent raises an error. However, you can create another instance of the Double Agent control and load the same character.
Loading a character does not automatically display the character. Use the method first to make the character visible.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Activate(System.Object)
member.summary: Sets the active client or character.
member.param:
An optional numeric value from the Enumeration:
0 = Inactive
Your client application is not the character's active client.
1 = Active
Your client application is the character's active client.
2 = InputActive
The character is the input-active character and will receive user input.
4 = Suspended
Your client application is inactive, and is not the character's active client.
5 = Suspended_Active
Your client application is inactive, and is the character's active client.
6 = Suspended_InputActive
Your client application is inactive, and the character will be input-active when your application becomes active.
member.returns: True if the method succeeded.

remarks.para: Avoid calling this method directly after a method. automatically sets the input-active client. When the character is shown, the Activate call may fail if it gets processed before the method completes.
remarks.note: Calling this method with set to 1 () does not typically generate an event unless there are no other characters loaded or your application is already input-active.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.GenerateIcon(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates a notification icon from one frame of the character's animations.
member.param: An optional numeric value that specifies the left side of the clipping area. The default value is 0.
An optional numeric value that specifies the top of the clipping area. The default value is 0.
An optional numeric value that specifies the width of the clipping area. The default value is -1, meaning the full width of the animation frame.
An optional numeric value that specifies the height of the clipping area. The default value is -1, meaning the full width of the animation frame.

remarks.para: The icon is generated using the first frame of one of the character's animations as the source of the icon image. Which animation is used depends on which animations the character supports.
You can specify an optional clipping area to generate the icon from only a part of the animation frame.
If you don't specify a clipping area, the entire image is used (with any empty space around the edges removed).
remarks.note: You can only use this method once per character. Once a notification icon has been generated, it cannot be changed.
If you use this method for a character that has a notification icon in its definition, the defined icon is replaced by the generated icon for as long as the character is loaded.

A numeric value that indicates the vertical screen coordinate, in pixels, to which the character will gesture.
member.returns: A Object your application can use to track the method's status.

remarks.para: Double Agent automatically plays the appropriate animation to gesture toward the specified location. The coordinates are always relative to the upper left corner of the screen.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Hide(System.Object)
member.summary: Hides the character.
member.param: A boolean value that indicates whether to skip the character's Hiding state animation.
member.returns: A Object your application can use to track the method's status.

remarks.para: Double Agent queues the actions of the Hide method in the character's queue, so you can use it to hide the character after a sequence of other animations. You can play the action immediately by using the or method before calling this method.
remarks.note: Hiding a character can trigger the event of another client.
Hidden characters cannot access the screen or the audio channel. Double Agent will pass a failure status in the event if you attempt to animate a hidden character.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Interrupt(DoubleAgent.Control.Request)
member.summary: Interrupts an animation for another character.
member.param: The Object for the animation call you want to interrupt.
member.returns: A Object your application can use to track the method's status.

remarks.para: You can use this to synchronize animation between characters. For example, if another character is in a looping animation, this method will stop the loop and move to the next animation in the character's queue.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Listen(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Turns on Listening mode (speech recognition) for a timed period.
member.param: A boolean value that determines whether to turn Listening mode on or off.
member.returns: True if Listening mode was started.

remarks.para: Setting the parameter to True enables Listening mode (turns on speech recognition) for a fixed period of time (10 seconds). While you cannot set the value of the time-out, you can turn off Listening mode before the time-out expires.

If you (or another client) successfully set Listening mode on and you attempt to set this property to True before the time-out expires, the method succeeds and resets the time-out. However, if the Listening mode is on because the user is pressing the Listening key, the method succeeds, but the time-out is ignored and Listening mode ends based on the user's interaction with the Listening key.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.MoveTo(System.Int16,System.Int16,System.Object)
member.summary: Moves the character to the specified location.
member.param: The horizontal location, in pixels, relative to the left side of the screen.
The vertical location, in pixels, relative to the top of the screen.
An optional numeric value specifying how quickly the character's image moves, in milliseconds. The default value is 1000. Specifying zero moves the image without playing an animation.
member.returns: A Object your application can use to track the method's status.

remarks.para: The location of a character is based on the upper left corner of its image. Double Agent automatically plays the appropriate animation assigned to the Moving states.
remarks.note: The parameter's actual effect may vary based on the computer's processor speed and the priority of other tasks running on the system.

If you call MoveTo with a non-zero before the character is shown, it will return a failure status if you assigned a Object, because the non-zero value indicates that you're attempting to play an animation when the character isn't visible.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Play(System.String)
member.summary: Plays the specified animation.
member.param: A string value that specifies the name of an animation sequence.
member.returns: A Object your application can use to track the method's status.

remarks.para: An animation's name is defined when the character is authored. Before playing the specified animation, Double Agent attempts to play the Return animation for the previous animation, if one has been assigned.
The Play method does not make the character visible. If the character is not visible, Double Agent plays the animation invisibly, and sets the property of the Object.

When accessing a character's animations using a conventional file protocol, you can simply use thePlay method specifying the name of the animation. However, if you're using the HTTP protocol to access character animation data, use the method to load the animation before calling the Play method.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Prepare(DoubleAgent.Control.PrepareResourceType,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Retrieves the specified animation data for the a remote character.
member.param:
One of the following members of the Enumeration:
0 = Animation
Download an animation.
1 = State
Download all animations for a state.
2 = Wave
Download a sound file.

A string that indicates the name of the animation resource.
For animations, the name is one of those defined for the character when it was authored.
For states, the name is one of those defined for the character when it was authored. See the property for details.
For audio files, specify the location of the .WAV file. If an incomplete path is specified, it's interpreted as being relative to the location used in the method.
You can specify multiple animations and states by separating them with commas. However, you cannot mix types in the same Prepare call.
A boolean value specifying whether the Double Agent queues the Prepare, or starts it immediately.
member.returns: A Object your application can use to track the method's status.

remarks.para: If you load a character using the HTTP protocol (an .ACF file), you should use the Prepare method to retrieve animation data before you play the animation. You do not use this method if you loaded the character using the UNC protocol (an .ACS file).

Using the Prepare method is not mandatory. If Double Agent requires an animation from an .ACS file, it will load the file automatically (from the same location the .ACF file was loaded). However, this may cause unexpected delays when using the HTTP protocol.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Show(System.Object)
member.summary: Shows the character and optionally plays its associated Showing animation.
member.param: A boolean value specifying whether or not the Showing state animation is played.
member.returns: A Object your application can use to track the method's status.

remarks.para: Avoid setting the parameter to True without first playing an animation; otherwise, the character may be shown with no image. In particular, note that if you call when the character is not visible, it does not play any animation. Therefore, if you call the Show method with set to True, no image will display. Similarly, if you call , then Show with set to True, there will be no visible image.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.ShowPopupMenu(System.Int16,System.Int16)
member.summary: Displays the character's pop-up menu at the specified location.
member.param: The horizontal screen coordinate to display the menu, in pixels.
The vertical screen coordinate to display the menu, in pixels.
member.returns: True if the method succeeded.

remarks.para: If the property is set to True, Double Agent automatically displays the character's pop-up menu when the user right-clicks the character. If you set to False, you can use ShowPopupMenu to display the menu.

The menu remains displayed until the user selects a command or displays another menu. Only one pop-up menu can be displayed at a time; therefore, calls to this method will cancel (remove) the former menu.

This method should be called only when your client application is the active client of the character; otherwise it fails. To determine the success of this method you can call it as a function and it will return a boolean value indicating whether the method succeeded.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Speak(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Speaks the specified text or sound file.
member.param: A string value that specifies what the character says.

A string value specifying the location of an audio file (.WAV format). The location can be specified as a file (including a UNC path specification) or URL (when character animation data is also being retrieved via HTTP protocol).
member.returns: A Object your application can use to track the method's status.

remarks.para: At least one of the and parameters must be supplied. To use this method with a character configured to speak only in its word balloon or using a text-to-speech (TTS) engine, simply provide the parameter. Include a space between words to define appropriate word breaks in the word balloon, even for languages that do not traditionally include spaces.
You can also include vertical bar '|' characters in the parameter to designate alternative strings, so that Double Agent randomly chooses a different string each time it processes the method.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Stop(System.Object)
member.summary: Stops an animation.
member.param: A Object specifying a particular animation call, or a null reference to stop all animations.

remarks.para: To specify the parameter, you must create a variable and assign the animation request you want to stop. If you don't set the parameter, Double Agent stops all animations for the character, including queued calls, and clears its animation queue (unless the character is currently playing its Hiding or Showing animation).
remarks.note: This method is performed immediately and does not generate a Object.
This method does not stop immediate calls.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.StopAll(System.Object)
member.summary: Stops all animation requests or specified types of requests.
member.param:
You can omit this parameter you or use any combination of the following members of the Enumeration:
&H00000001 = Play
Stop any pending or running animations.
&H00000002 = Move
Stop any pending or running move requests.
&H00000004 = Speak
Stop any pending or running speech requests.
&H00000008 = QueuedPrepare
Stop any queued animation or file downloads (Prepare method with Queue parameter set to True).
&H00000010 = ImmediatePrepare
Stop any non-queued animation or file downloads (Prepare method with Queue parameter set to False)
&H00000020 = Visibility
Stop any pending show or hide requests.
&HFFFFFFFF = Everything
Stop all pending requests.
You can use a string value instead, with one or more of the following values, separated with commas:
"Play" StopAllFlags.Play
"Move" StopAllFlags.Move
"Speak" StopAllFlags.Speak
"QueuedPrepare" (or "Get" for compatibility) StopAllFlags.QueuedPrepare
"ImmediatePrepare" (or "NonQueuedGet" for compatibility) StopAllFlags.ImmediatePrepare
"Visibility" or "Visible" StopAllFlags.Visibility
"Everything" or "All" StopAllFlags.Everything

remarks.para: If you don't set the parameter, Double Agent stops all animations for the character, including queued and immediate requests, and clears its animation queue. It also stops playing a character's Hiding or Showing animation.
This method is performed immediately and does not generate a Object.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Think(System.String)
member.summary: Displays the specified text in the character's thought word balloon.
member.param: A string value that specifies the character's thought output.
member.returns: A Object your application can use to track the method's status.

remarks.para: Like the method, the Think method is a queued request that displays text in a word balloon, except that the Think word balloon differs visually. In addition, the word balloon supports only the bookmark speech control tag (Mrk) and ignores any other speech control tags. Unlike , the Think method does not change the character's animation state.
The Object's properties affect the output of both the and Think methods. For example, the Object's property must be True for text to display.

Agent's automatic word breaking in the word balloon breaks words using white-space characters (for example, SPACE or TAB). However, if it cannot, it may break a word to fit the word balloon. In languages like Japanese, Chinese, and Thai where spaces are not used to break words, insert a Unicode zero-width space character (0x200B) between characters to define logical word breaks.
remarks.note: To track the method's status, you can declare an object reference and set it to the method's Object return value.
Set the character's before using the Think method to ensure appropriate text display within the word balloon.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Wait(DoubleAgent.Control.Request)
member.summary: Causes the character's animation queue to wait until the specified animation request completes.
member.param: A Object specifying the animation to wait for.
member.returns: A Object your application can use to track the method's status.

remarks.para: Use this method only when you are using multiple (simultaneous) characters and are trying to sequence the interaction of characters. (For a single character, each animation request is played sequentially--after the previous request completes.)
If you have two characters and you want one character's animation request to wait until the other character's animation completes, use the Wait method with the other character's animation Object.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Active
member.summary: deprecated

remarks.para: This property has been replaced by the property, but is still supported for backward compatibility.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.ActiveState
member.summary: Indicates if your application is the character's active client and if the character is input-active.
member.value:
A member of the Enumeration indicating the state of the character and your client application:
0 = Inactive
Your client application is not the character's active client.
1 = Active
Your client application is the character's active client.
2 = InputActive
The character is the input-active character and will receive user input.
4 = Suspended
Your client application is inactive, and is not the character's active client.
5 = Suspended_Active
Your client application is inactive, and is the character's active client.
6 = Suspended_InputActive
Your client application is inactive, and the character will be input-active when your application becomes active.

remarks.para: When multiple client applications share the same character, the character's active client receives mouse input (for example, Double Agent control Click or Drag events). Similarly, when multiple characters are displayed, the active client of the topmost character (also known as the input-active client) receives Command events.
You can use the method to set whether your application is the character's active client or to make your application the input-active client (which also makes the character topmost).

remarks.para: By setting this property to False, you can create your own menu-handling behaviour. To display the menu after setting this property to False, use the method.
remarks.note: This property applies only to your client application's use of the character; the setting does not affect other clients of the character or other characters of your client application.

member.summary: Indicates if the specified character is in use by other applications.

If your application uses multiple instances of the Object, each instance is a treated as a different client and this property will return True.

member.summary: Specifies the height of the character's image.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.IconIdentity
member.summary: Specifies the identity that Windows will use to remember the character's notification icon.
member.value: A string value that allows Windows to uniquely identify this character's notification icon. It must be either a valid GUID string or an empty string.

remarks.para: Every notification icon has an identity that allows Windows to remember it's state (shown, hidden, active, etc.). By default, Windows associates a notification icon with the application that creates it.
You can supply either a GUID identifier, or an empty string to use the default identity.

list.item: If the character was loaded by the Double Agent server, it's notification icon will be associated with the server by default.
If you're using the control in stand-alone mode, the character's notification icon will be associated with your client application by default.
You can supply a single GUID for all characters you load. All of their notification icons will be associated with that single identity.
You can supply a unique GUID for each character you load. Windows will then identify each character's notification icon uniquely.

remarks.note: This property applies only to your client application's use of the character; the setting does not affect other clients of the character or other characters of your client application.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.IconShown
member.summary: Specifies if the character's notification icon is shown in the Windows notification area.
member.value: A boolean value that indicates if the icon is shown.

remarks.para: This property only specifies if the notification icon is added to the Windows notification area. The user decides whether it's visible or hidden. See the property for more details.
remarks.note: This property has no effect if the character doesn't have a notification icon.
This property applies only to your client application's use of the character; the setting does not affect other clients of the character or other characters of your client application.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.IconTip
member.summary: Specifies the tip text associated with the character's notification icon.
member.value: A string value that specifies the notification icon's tip text. An empty string means that the default tip (the character's name) is used.

remarks.para: By default, the character's is shown in the notification icon tip. You can use this property to show your own tip.
remarks.note: This property applies only to your client application's use of the character; the setting does not affect other clients of the character or other characters of your client application.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.IconVisible
member.summary: Indicates if the character has a notification icon in the Windows notification area.
member.value: A boolean value that indicates if the character is showing a notification icon.

remarks.para: This property only indicates if the notification icon has been created. The user decides if the icon is actually visible or hidden.

The style only applies to your client application, so it is only in effect when you application is the character's active client. When your application is not the character's active client, you can use this property to determine if another client has shown or hidden the notification icon.
remarks.note: This property applies to all clients of the character.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.IdleEnabled
member.summary: Specifies if the character will show its Idling animations when it's not busy.
member.value: A boolean value specifying whether Double Agent manages idle mode.

remarks.para: Double Agent automatically sets a time-out after the last animation played for a character. When this timer's interval is complete, Double Agent begins the Idling state for a character, playing its associated Idling animations at regular intervals. If you want to disable Double Agent from automatically playing the Idling state animations, set the property to False and play an animation or call the method. Setting this value does not affect the current animation state of the character.
remarks.note: This property applies only to your client application's use of the character; the setting does not affect other clients of the character or other characters of your client application.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.IdleOn
member.summary: deprecated

remarks.para: This property has been replaced by the property, but is still supported for backward compatibility.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.IdleState
member.summary: Indicates if the character is currently playing its Idling animations.
member.value: A boolean value that indicates if the character is idling.

remarks.note: This property applies to all clients of the character.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.LanguageID
member.summary: Specifies the character's language identifier.
member.value: A numeric value specifying the character's language ID. A character's language ID (LANGID) is a 16-bit value defined by Windows, consisting of a primary language ID and a secondary language ID.

remarks.para: If you do not set the character's LanguageID, its language will be the current system language, if the corresponding Agent language DLL is installed. Otherwise, the character's language will be English (US).

This property also determines the language for word balloon text, the commands in the character's pop-up menu, and the speech recognition engine. It also determines the default language for text-to-speech output.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Left
member.summary: Specifies the left edge of the character's image.
member.value: A numeric value that specifies the left edge of the character's image.

remarks.para: The Left property is always expressed in pixels, relative to screen origin (upper left).

Even though the character appears in an irregularly shaped region window, the location of the character is based on the external dimensions of the rectangular animation frame used when the character was compiled with the Microsoft® Agent Character Editor.
remarks.note: This property applies to all clients of the character.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.ListeningStatus
member.summary: Indicates if speech input can be started for the character.
member.value:
One of the following members of the Enumeration:
0 = Available
Conditions support speech input.
2 = CharacterInactive
Speech recognition is unavailable because another client is the active client of this character, or the current character is not input-active.
4 = InitializeFailed
Speech recognition is unavailable because it could not be initialized. This includes the possibility that there is no speech engine available matching the character's language setting.
5 = InputDisabled
The user has disabled speech input in the Advanced Character Options window.
6 = Error
The speech recognition status could not be determined.

remarks.para: This property checks for the conditions necessary to support speech input. You can check this property before you call the method to better ensure its success.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.MoveCause
member.summary: Returns the cause of the character's last move.
member.value:
One of the following members of the Enumeration:
0 = NeverMoved
The character hasn't moved.
1 = UserMoved
The user dragged the character.
2 = ProgramMoved
Your client application moved the character.
3 = OtherProgramMoved
Another client application moved the character.

remarks.para: You can use this property to determine what caused the character to move, when more than one application is sharing (has loaded) the same character. These values are the same as those returned by the event.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Name
member.summary: Specifies the specified character's displayed name.
member.value: A string value corresponding to the character's name (in the current language setting).

remarks.para: A character's Name may depend on the character's setting. A character's name in one language may be different or use different characters than in another. The character's default Name for a specific language is defined when the character is compiled with the Microsoft® Agent Character Editor.

Avoid renaming a character, especially when using it in a scenario where other client applications may use the same character. Also, Double Agent uses the character's Name to automatically create commands for hiding and showing the character.
remarks.note: This property applies to all clients of the character.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.OriginalHeight

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.OriginalWidth

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Pitch
member.summary: Returns the character's default speech output (text-to-speech) pitch setting.
member.value: A numeric value that specifies the pitch (in hertz) of the character'sdefault text-to-speech engine.

remarks.para: This property is of limited value since it only supplies the default pitch from the character's definition. It's supported for compatibility.

Although your application cannot write this value, you can include Pit (pitch) tags in your speech output text that will temporarily change the pitch for a particular utterance. However, using the Pit tag to change the pitch will not change the Pitch property value. For further information, see Speech Output Tags.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Smoothed
member.summary: Indicates if image smoothing is being applied to the character's animations.
member.value: A boolean value that indicates if animation frames are smoothed.

remarks.para: Agent character animations are defined with an 8-bit color depth (256 color palette), which can result in low image quality and visible pixilation. Image smoothing reduces pixilation by applying a slight blur to each animation frame.
remarks.note: This is a read-only property. Its value is initialized from the . property.
This property applies to all clients of the character.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.SmoothEdges
member.summary: Indicates if image smoothing is being applied to the edges of the character's animations.
member.value: A boolean value that indicates if animation frames have smoothed edges.

remarks.para: Agent character animations are defined with an 8-bit color depth (256 color palette), which can result in low image quality and visible pixilation. Edge smoothing reduces pixilation by applying a slight blur to the edges of each animation frame.
remarks.note: This is a read-only property. Its value is initialized from the . property.
This property applies to all clients of the character.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.SoundEffectsEnabled
member.summary: Specifies if sound effects are enabled for your character.
member.value: A boolean value specifying whether sound effects are enabled.

remarks.para: This property determines whether the sound effects included as a part of a character's animations will play when an animation plays.
remarks.note: This property applies only to your client application's use of the character; the setting does not affect other clients of the character or other characters of your client application.
This settings can be overridden by the user in the Advanced Character Options window.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.SoundEffectsOn

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Speed

remarks.para: This property is of limited value since it only supplies the default speed from the character's definition, scaled by the property. It's supported for compatibility.

However, using the Spd tag to change the character's spoken output does not affect the Speed property value. For further information, see Speech Output Tags.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Style
member.summary: Specifies a group of settings that affect the character's appearance.
member.value:
A numeric bit-field value that has one or more of the following:
&H00000001 = SoundEffects
The animation sound effects are played.
&H00000002 = IdleEnabled
The character enters idle mode and shows it's idling animations when it's not doing anything else.
&H00000004 = AutoPopupMenu
A right-click on the character or it's notification icon automatically shows a pop-up menu.
&H00000008 = IconShown
The character has a notification icon in the taskbar notification area.
&H00000020 = SmoothEdges
Image smoothing (antialiasing) is applied to the edges of the character's animations.
&H00000030 = Smoothed
Image smoothing (antialiasing) is applied to the character's animations.
&H00000100 = SuspendPause
All requests are paused when the client is not in the foreground.
&H00000200 = SuspendStop
All requests are stopped when the client is not in the foreground.
&H00000400 = SuspendHide
All floating windows are hidden when the client is not in the foreground.

remarks.para: Each style bit corresponds to a specific Object property. You can use this property to query or modify all of the style settings at once.
The and bits are read-only. They can only be set in the . property before the is loaded.

member.summary: Returns the unique identifier given to the character when it was defined.
member.value: A string value containing the the character's unique (GUID) identifier.

remarks.para: This property returns a string representing the internal identifier that Double Agent uses to uniquely identify the character. A character identifier is set when it is compiled with the Microsoft® Agent Character Editor.
remarks.note: This is the value that Double Agent uses to determine if a character has already been loaded. The character's file name or location does not uniquely identify the character.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Version
member.summary: Returns the character's version.
member.value: A string that identifies the Microsoft® Agent version for which the character was built.

remarks.para: The Version property returns a string that corresponds to the version of the standard animation set definition for which the character was compiled. The character's version number is automatically set when you build it with the Microsoft® Agent Character Editor.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.VisibilityCause
member.summary: Returns a Enumeration value that specifies what caused the character's visible state to change.
member.value:
A Enumeration value:
0 = NeverShown
The character has not been shown.
1 = UserHid
The user hid the character using the command on the character's notification icon or using speech input.
2 = UserShowed
The user showed the character using the command on the character's notification icon or using speech input.
3 = ProgramHid
Your application hid the character.
4 = ProgramShowed
Your application showed the character.
5 = OtherProgramHid
Another client application hid the character.
6 = OtherProgramShowed
Another client application showed the character.

remarks.para: You can use this property to determine what caused the character to change visibility when more than one application is sharing (has loaded) the same character. These values are the same as those received by the and events.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Visible
member.summary: Returns a boolean indicating whether or not the character is visible.
member.value: True if the character is displayed, False if it's hidden

remarks.para: This property indicates whether the character's animations are being displayed. It does not necessarily mean that there is an image on the screen. For example, this property returns True even when the character is positioned off the visible display area or when the current character animation contains no images.
This property is read-only. To change a character's visibility, use the or method.
remarks.note: This property applies to all clients of the character.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.Width
member.summary: Specifies the width of the character's image.
member.value: A numeric value that specifies the width of the character's image.

remarks.para: The Width property is always expressed in pixels.

Even though the character appears in an irregularly shaped region window, the dimensions of the character are based on the external dimensions of the rectangular animation frame used when the character was compiled with the Microsoft® Agent Character Editor.
remarks.note: This property applies to all clients of the character.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.Character.NewFormattedText
member.summary: Returns an initialized, empty Object.
member.returns: A Object.

remarks.para: The returned Object is initialized to handle speech tags consistent with the current Text-to-Speech engine.

Once you have completed the Object, you can pass it to either the or method. If you plan to use the same text more than once, keep a reference to the Object and reuse it. This can improve the performance of your application.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Commands.GlobalVoiceCommandsEnabled
member.summary: Specifies if pre-defined commands appear in the Voice Commands window.
member.value: A boolean value that indicates if global voice commands are enabled.

remarks.para: Double Agent automatically adds voice commands (grammar) for opening and closing the Voice Commands window and for showing and hiding the character. If you set GlobalVoiceCommandsEnabled to False, Agent disables any voice parameters for these voice commands as well as the voice commands for the of other clients' Collection. This allows you to eliminate these from your client's current active grammar. However, because this potentially blocks voice access to other clients, reset this property to True after processing the user's voice input.
Disabling the property does not affect the character's pop-up menu. The global commands added by Double Agent will still appear; you cannot remove them from the pop-up menu.

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.Command
member.summary: A Command Object is an item in a Collection. Double Agent provides the user access to your Command Objects when your client application becomes input-active.

remarks.para: A command may appear in either the character's pop-up menu and the Voice Commands window, or in both. To appear in the pop-up menu it must have a and have the property set to True. In addition, its Collection's property must also be set to True. To appear in the Voice Commands window, a Command must have its and properties set.

When Double Agent receives input for one of your commands, it sends a event, and passes back the name of the Command as an attribute of the Object. You can then use conditional statements to match and process the Command.

Note that a character's pop-up menu entries do not change while the menu is displayed. If you add or remove commands or change their properties while the character's pop-up menu is displayed, the menu reflects those changes whenever the user next shows it. However, the Voice Commands window dynamically reflects any changes you make.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Balloon.BackColor
member.summary: Specifies the background color of a character's word balloon.
member.value: A numeric value that specifies the background color.

remarks.para: The valid range for a normal RGB color is 0 to 16,777,215 (&HFFFFFF). The high byte of a number in this range equals 0; the lower 3 bytes, from least to most significant byte, determine the amount of red, green, and blue, respectively. The red, green, and blue components are each represented by a number between 0 and 255 (&HFF).
remarks.note: This property applies only to your client application's use of the character; the setting does not affect other clients of the character or other characters of your client application.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Balloon.BorderColor

The red, green, and blue components are each represented by a number between 0 and 255 (&HFF).

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Balloon.Enabled
member.summary: Indicates if the word balloon is enabled for a character.
member.value: A boolean value that indicates if the style is set.

remarks.para: When the style is set, the word balloon appears when the or method is used, unless the user overrides this setting in the Advanced Character Options window. When it's not set, the word balloon does not appear.

The default enabled style is set as part of a character's definition when the character is compiled in the Microsoft® Agent Character Editor. If a character is defined to not support the word balloon, this property will always be False for the character.
The user can override the enabled style for all characters in the Advanced Character Options window.

remarks.note: If you're using a character that you didn't compile, check the and FontCharSet properties for the character to determine whether they are appropriate for your locale. You may need to set these values before using the method to ensure appropriate text display within the word balloon.
This property applies only to your client application's use of the character; the setting does not affect other clients of the character or other characters of your client application.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Balloon.Style
member.summary: Specifies the character's word balloon output style.
member.value:
An numeric value that represents the word balloon's output style. The style value is a bit field with bits defined as follows:
bit 0 (&H00000001)
bit 1 (&H00000002)
bit 2 (&H00000004)
bit 3 (&H00000008)
bit 4 (&H00000010)
bits 16-23
bits 24-31

remarks.para: All of the settings included in the Style property can be accessed using specific Object properties. The Style property lets you retrieve or set all of these settings at once.
The defaults for the Style property are set when the character is compiled with the Microsoft® Agent Character Editor.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Balloon.Visible
member.summary: Specifies the visibility of a character's word balloon.
member.value: A boolean value that indicates if the word balloon is visible.

remarks.para: If you follow a or call with a statement that changes this property, it may not affect the Visible state because the or call gets queued, but the call to set this property does not. Therefore, only set this value when no or calls are in the character's request queue.
If you attempt to set this property while the character is speaking, moving, or being dragged, the property setting does not take effect until the preceding operation is completed.

Calling the and methods automatically makes the word balloon visible, setting the Visible property to True. If the property is enabled, the word balloon is automatically hidden after the text output is complete. Clicking or dragging a character that is not currently speaking also automatically hides the word balloon, even if its setting is disabled.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Balloon.AutoHide
member.summary: Indicates if the word balloon will be automatically hidden after all of its text has been shown.
member.value: A boolean value that indicates if the style is enabled.

remarks.para: When the style is set, the word balloon automatically hides when spoken output completes. When it's not set, the word balloon remains displayed until the next or call, the character is hidden, or the user clicks or drags the character.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Balloon.AutoPace
member.summary: Indicates if the word balloon paces its text display to the speech output.
member.value: A boolean value that indicates if the style is enabled.

remarks.para: When the style is set, the word balloon paces its text output based on the current output rate, for example one word at a time. When output exceeds the size of the word balloon, the text is automatically scrolled. When it's not set, all text included in a or request is displayed at once.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Balloon.ShowPartialLines
member.summary: Indicates if the word balloon shows partial lines when it scrolls.
member.value: A boolean value that indicates if the style is enabled.

remarks.para: When the style is set, the word balloon will show partial lines at the bottom as it scrolls its text. When it's not set, only full lines are shown. This style only applies when the style is not set.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Balloon.SizeToText
member.summary: Indicates if the word balloon is automatically resized to fit it's contents.
member.value: A boolean value that indicates if the style is enabled.

remarks.para: When the style is set, the word balloon automatically adjusts the height of the word balloon to the current size of the text for the or request. When it's not set, the word balloon's height is based on the property. If this style is set and you attempt to set the property, Double Agent raises an error.

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.Balloon
member.summary:
Double Agent supports textual captioning of the method using a cartoon word balloon. The method lets you display text without audio output in a thought word balloon.
The Balloon Object allows you to customize the appearance and behaviour of a character's word balloon.

remarks.para: A character's initial word balloon defaults are defined and compiled in the Microsoft® Agent Character Editor. Once running, the Balloon Object's Enabled and Font properties may be overridden by the user. If a user changes the balloon's properties, they affect all characters. Both the and balloons use the same property settings for size. You can access the properties for a character's word balloon through the Balloon Object, which is a child of the Object.
This object can be accessed using the Object's property.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Request.Description
member.summary: Returns a description of a request error .
member.value: A string value that corresponds to the error Number. If no description is found for an error, Description contains "Application-defined or object-defined error".

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Request.Number
member.summary: Returns the error or cause of the code.
member.value: The error or cause of the Status code. If there is no error, this value is zero.

remarks.para: For the values and meanings of the Number property, see Double Agent Error Codes.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Request.Status
member.summary: You can use the Status property to check the status of your request.
member.value:
The current status of the request:
0 = Success
The request was successfully completed.
1 = Failed
The request failed and an error code is available in the Object's property.
2 = Pending
The request is on the queue.
3 = Interrupted
The request was interrupted and an error code is available in the Object's property.
4 = InProgress
The request is currently in progress.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Request.ID
member.summary: Returns the server's unique identifier for the request.
member.value: A numeric value used by the server to uniquely identify the request.

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.Request
member.summary: Double Agent processes some methods, such as , , and , asynchronously. This allows your application code to continue while the method is completing. When a client application calls one of these methods, the control queues the request and returns a Request Object. The Request Object allows you to check the status of your request by keeping a reference to the object.

remarks.para: If you create a Request Object reference, Double Agent automatically notifies you when an animation request has started or completed through the and events. Because methods that return Request Objects are asynchronous and may not complete during the scope of the calling function, declare your reference to the Request Object globally.
The following methods can return a Request Object: , , , , , , , , , , and .

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.UserInput
member.summary: Double Agent sends the event when your application is input-active and the user chooses a command from the character's pop-up menu or by spoken input. The event passes a UserInput Object that identifies the number of possible matching commands as well as the name, confidence scoring, and voice text for those matches.

remarks.para: Not all speech recognition engines may return all the values for all the properties of this object. Check with your engine vendor to determine whether the engine supports the Microsoft® Speech API interface for returning alternatives and confidence scores.

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.PropertySheet
member.summary: The PropertySheet Object provides access to the Advanced Character Options window. It allows you to show and hide the window, and retrieve and update the window's location and current page.

remarks.note: The Advanced Character Options window combines the Microsoft® Agent Advanced Character Options and Default Character Properties windows.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.Settings.AudioStatus
member.summary: Returns the status of the audio output channel.
member.value:
A member of the Enumeration that indicates the current audio output status:
0 = Available
Text-to-speech is available.
1 = Disabled
Text-to-speech is disabled in the Advanced Character Options window.
3 = UserSpeaking
Listening mode is active and the user is currently speaking.
4 = CharacterSpeaking
A character is currently speaking.
5 = CharacterListening
Listening mode is active.
6 = Error
The audio status could not be determined.

remarks.para: Your client application can use this property to determine whether it is appropriate to have your character speak or whether it is appropriate to try to turn on Listening mode (using the method).

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.FormattedText.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Parses text containing speech tags.
member.param: A string value containing text with optional speech output tags.

remarks.para: The kind of speech tags accepted depends on the Text-to-Speech engine selected for the when the Object was created. If the is using a SAPI4 speech engine, then SAPI4 speech tags are accepted. If the is using a SAPI5 speech engine, then SAPI5 speech tags and supported SAPI4 speech tags are accepted. Any supported SAPI4 tags are converted to SAPI5 tags.
For more information about speech tags, see Speech Output Tags.
remarks.note: This method will fail if the Object is currently being used by a queued speech or thought action.

member.value: A string value that uniquely identifies the speech recognition engine.

remarks.para: This property corresponds to the . property. To use this Object, set the character's property to this value.

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.SREngine
member.summary: The SREngine Object provides information about an installed speech recognition engine. You can use it to help choose a character's speech recognition engine.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.SREngines.Count
member.summary: Returns the count of Objects in the Collection.
member.value: A numeric value that indicates the number of Objects in the collection.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.SREngines.Item(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a Object in the collection.
member.param:
A numeric value that specifies the zero-based index of the item to retrieve,
or a string value that specifies the of the item to retrieve.
member.value: The Object identified by .

remarks.para: When the Collection is retrieved using matching criteria (for example using the method), it is an ordered collection. It's items are in order from best to worst match.

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.SREngines
member.summary: The SREngines Collection contains a selected set of Objects. You can use it to help choose a character's speech recognition engine.

remarks.para: The contents of the collection depends on how it was retrieved.
When the Collection is retrieved using matching criteria (for example using the method), it is an ordered collection. It's items are in order from best to worst match.

member.name: M:DoubleAgent.Control.TTSEngine.GetVersion(System.Int16@,System.Int16@)
member.summary: Returns the text-to-speech engine's version.
member.param: A numeric values that identifies the engine's major version (always 4 or 5 at this time).
A numeric values that identifies the engine's minor version (always 0 at this time).

remarks.para: You can use this property to determine if the text-to-speech engine is a SAPI4 or SAPI5 engine.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.TTSEngine.DisplayName
member.summary: Returns the text-to-speech engine's human-readable name.
member.value: A string value gives the engine's name in a form suitable for the user.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.TTSEngine.Gender
member.summary: Returns the text-to-speech engine's gender.
member.value:
A numeric value that identifies the speech engine's gender:
1 = Female
A female voice.
2 = Male
A male voice.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.TTSEngine.LanguageID
member.summary: Returns the text-to-speech engine's language identifier.
member.value: A numeric value that identifies the language supported by the engine.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.TTSEngine.LanguageName(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the text-to-speech engine's human-readable language name.
member.value: A string value that identifies the engine's language in a form suitable for the user.
member.param: An optional boolean value that specifies if the language name should be in English, or in the user's language. The default value is True.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.TTSEngine.Manufacturer
member.summary: Returns the text-to-speech engine's manufacturer's name.
member.value: A string value that supplies the name of the engine's manufacturer.

remarks.para: Some text-to-speech engine engines may not supply this property.

member.name: P:DoubleAgent.Control.TTSEngine.TTSModeID
member.summary: Returns the unique identifier used to select this text-to-speech engine.
member.value: A string value that uniquely identifies a specific speech mode of a specific text-to-speech engine.

remarks.para: This property corresponds to the . property. To use this Object, set the character's property to this value.

member.name: T:DoubleAgent.Control.TTSEngine
member.summary: The TTSEngine Object provides information about an installed text-to-speech engine. You can use it to help choose a character's text-to-speech engine.

remarks.para: Some text-to-speech engines support several modes, generally one for each supported language or language variant. In that case, this object represents only one mode, and there will one TTSEngine Object for each mode supported by the speech engine, each with a unique property.
